title: Ticket #7023: Setting maximum history log file too large causes schedd crash
description:
I suddenly have a large population of jobs with extremely large arguments and environment variable strings that also happen to execute quickly. I have historically kept long history logs on the head nodes. My previous settings enabled 100 days of history with no file greater than 1GB in size. In practice, a day's worth of history is never near 1GB. It's just there to go above the default 20MB decisively. 

ENABLE_HISTORY_ROTATION = True
ROTATE_HISTORY_DAILY    = True
MAX_HISTORY_LOG         = 1000000000
MAX_HISTORY_ROTATIONS   = 100

But these settings suddenly became problematic because these jobs were creating 10 1GB files per day! So I tried 

MAX_HISTORY_LOG         = 10000000000
MAX_HISTORY_ROTATIONS   = 7

and the schedd crashed hard! 

05/01/19 14:00:46 (pid:3570401) Got SIGHUP.  Re-reading config files.
05/01/19 14:00:46 (pid:3570401) Loading classad userMap 'ValidSearchTags' ts=1556737202 from /etc/condor/accounting/valid_tags
05/01/19 14:00:46 (pid:3570401) Loading classad userMap 'ValidSearchUsers' ts=1556737201 from /etc/condor/accounting/valid_users
05/01/19 14:00:46 (pid:3570401) ERROR "MAX_HISTORY_LOG in the condor configuration is out of bounds for an integer (10000000000).  Please set it to an integer in the range -214
7483648 to 2147483647 (default 20971520)." at line 2202 in file /slots/20/dir_547223/userdir/.tmploK3AG/BUILD/condor-8.9.1/src/condor_utils/condor_config.cpp
05/01/19 14:00:46 (pid:3570401) Cron: Killing all jobs
05/01/19 14:00:46 (pid:3570401) CronJobList: Deleting all jobs
05/01/19 14:00:46 (pid:3570401) Cron: Killing all jobs
05/01/19 14:00:46 (pid:3570401) CronJobList: Deleting all jobs

It seems to me that the schedd should do something better than completely crash when the value for MAX_HISTORY_LOG is out of bounds.
remarks:
2019-May-01 16:01:11 by tpdownes:
What I'm trying to do is reasonably guarantee that I always retain a day's worth of history before the nightly cronjob that rsyncs the data off. By setting the file size to be very large, it gives me a good chance of doing that while also having the max rotations be set low.
